Epidemiology studies patterns of health and disease in defined populations of living beings in order to infer causes and effects. Historically, Koch's postulates have been used since the 19th century to decide if a microorganism was the cause of a disease. Informally, in attempting to estimate the causal effect of some variable "X" on another "Y", an instrument is a third variable "Z" which affects "Y" only through its effect on "X". For example, suppose a researcher wishes to estimate the causal effect of smoking on general health. Correlation between health and smoking does not imply that smoking causes poor health because other variables, such as depression, may affect both health and smoking, or because health may affect smoking. It is at best difficult and expensive to conduct controlled experiments on smoking status in the general population. The researcher may attempt to estimate the causal effect of smoking on health from observational data by using the tax rate for tobacco products as an instrument for smoking. The tax rate for tobacco products is a reasonable choice for an instrument because the researcher assumes that it can only be correlated with health through its effect on smoking.
